Article.Abstract: The spike (S) protein of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) is an important viral structural protein. Based on bioinformatics analysis, 10 antigenic peptides derived from the S protein sequence were selected and synthesized. The antigenicity and immunoreactivity of all the peptides were tested in vivo and in vitro. Four peptides (P6, P8, P9 and P10) which contain B cell epitopes of the S protein were identified, and P8 peptide was confirmed in vivo to have a potential in serological diagnosis. By using a syncytia formation model, we tested the neutralization ability of all 10 peptides and their corresponding antibodies. It is interesting to find that P8 and P9 peptides inhibited syncytia formation, suggesting that the P8 and P9 spanning regions may provide a good target for anti-SARS-CoV drug design. Our data suggest that we have identified peptides derived from the S protein of SARS-CoV, which are useful for SARS treatment and diagnosis.
Article.ArticleTitle: Synthetic peptides derived from SARS coronavirus S protein with diagnostic and therapeutic potential.
Article.Affiliations: Laboratory of Molecular Cell Biology, Shanghai Institutes for Biological Sciences, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Graduate School of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai 200031, China.
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Amino Acid Sequence; Blotting, Western; Computational Biology; Humans; Molecular Sequence Data; Peptides(chemistry; therapeutic use); SARS Virus(chemistry); Viral Proteins(chemistry)

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Rabbits were given booster immunizations on days 21 an 42 following primary immunization. Antisera were collected on day 49 following primary immunization.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The sera from peptide-immunized rabbits showed specific binding to the S protein as well as to the S1 fragment of the S protein, while no binding to the S2 fragment occurred. The S protein and its fragments were isolated from E. coli expressed protein. Binding was also observed to the native S protein from the lysates of SARS-CoV infected Vero E6 cells.

S protein-specific IgG was purified from sera from 10 SARS patients and the mixture containing IgG served as a template to determine its reaction with the peptide. The peptide showed a false positive response to the sera of 3 out of 6 normal individuals and was subsequently extended to 30 amino acids in length (PSSKRFQPFQQFGRDVSDFTDSVRDPKTSE) and reevaluated in an ELISA assay. The longer peptide showed higher immunoreactivity and higher specificity than the shorter peptide.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Rabbits were given booster immunizations on days 21 an 42 following primary immunization. Antisera were collected on day 49 following primary immunization.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Peptide-induced polyclonal antibodies were analyzed for their ability to inhibit syncytia formation as an indicator of their virus neutralizing activity (syncytia formation was used to mimic the SARS-CoV infection procedure). When the peptide itself was used in this model, significant syncytia formation inhibition was observed.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Rabbits were given booster immunizations on days 21 an 42 following primary immunization. Antisera were collected on day 49 following primary immunization.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The sera from peptide-immunized rabbits did not show specific binding to the S protein or its S1 and S2 fragments. The S protein and its fragments were isolated from E. coli expressed protein. Binding was also not observed to the native S protein from the lysates of SARS-CoV infected Vero E6 cells. The peptide was also analyzed for its ability to inhibit syncytia formation as an indicator of its virus neutralizing activity (syncytia formation was used to mimic the SARS-CoV infection procedure). No significant syncytia formation inhibition was observed.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Rabbits were given booster immunizations on days 21 an 42 following primary immunization. Antisera were collected on day 49 following primary immunization.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The sera from peptide-immunized rabbits showed specific binding to the S protein as well as to its S2 fragment, while no binding to the S1 fragment was observed. The S protein and its fragments were isolated from E. coli expressed protein. Binding was also observed to the native S protein from the lysates of SARS-CoV infected Vero E6 cells.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Rabbits were given booster immunizations on days 21 an 42 following primary immunization. Antisera were collected on day 49 following primary immunization.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Peptide-induced polyclonal antibodies were analyzed for their ability to inhibit syncytia formation as an indicator of their virus neutralizing activity (syncytia formation was used to mimic the SARS-CoV infection procedure).

S protein-specific IgG was purified from sera from SARS patients and a mixture containing IgG served as a template to determine its reaction with the peptide. The peptide showed higher immunoreactivity and higher specificity than the shorter peptide, PSSKRFQPFQQFGRDVSDFT, which was also studied. No response to healthy controls was observed.
